BODY.H2: Water Quality of Large Discharges from Mines in the Anthracite Region of Eastern Pennsylvania

DL.DD: Water Quality of Large Discharges from Mines in the Anthracite Region of Eastern Pennsylvania
Origionally Published by USGS, Updated by EPCAMR

DL.DT: Originator:Charles R. Wood, US Geologic Survey
DL.DD: Water Quality of Large Discharges from Mines in the Anthracite Region of Eastern Pennsylvania
In Cooperation with the Pennsylvania Department of Conservation and Natural Resources Bureau of Topographic and Geologic Survey

DIV.PRE: Water Quality of the Large Discharges from Mines in the Anthracite Region of Eastern Pennsylvania
Developed by USGS to showcase the locations and water quality of the anthracite discharges
Updated by EPCAMR (2004-Current) to include additional sites identified in watershed assessment reports and additional attributes such as elevation and dissolved oxygen.
ground condition

DL.DT: Access_Constraints:Data is not classified and available to the public.

DIV.PRE: Data is to be used for educational or demonstrational purposes only.

DL.DT: Contact_Organization:Eastern Pennsylvania Coalition for Abandoned Mine Reclamation (EPCAMR)

DIV.PRE: 101 South Main Street
Given to EPCAMR by Charles Cravatta, USGS, New Cumberland, PA 2003

DL.DD: Version 6.2 (Build 9200) ; Esri ArcGIS 10.4.1.5686

DIV.PRE: Chemical and Physical Attributes were sampled several times from early 1960s to the late 1990s. Data represented within the attribute table is from the year 1975 when the most complete information is available, or averaged and interpolated when no data was present.
Origional data set from the USGS included 279 records with water quality from 1975.
The 2001 USGS report does not show all the discharges in the Anthracite Reion of Eastern PA, but only the largest. EPCAMR adds points or adjust existing points as new discharges are located.

With field verification, many of the discharge points are within acceptable deviation from their actual location, however some were as far off as 500 meters based on the 1990's era GPS technology. EPCAMR adjusted points with heads up identification of sources on aerial photography from the PA DCNR PAMAP program. Discharge locations can change over time with changes in underground hydrology or reclamation of the area.

With field verification, many of the discharge points are within acceptable deviation from their actual locationhowever some were as far off as 500 meters based on the 1990's era GPS technology. EPCAMR added elevations based on LiDAR derrived 2-foot contour mapping from the PA DCNR PAMAP program. Discharge locations can change over time with changes in underground hydrology or reclamation of the area.
Dataset copied from USGS Dataset provided by Charles Cravatta, USGS, New Cumberland, PA

DIV.PRE: 840 Market St.

New datapoints heads up digitized over USGS Topoquads matched to maps from The Impact of Mining on the Newport and Nanticoke Creek Watersheds, Luzerne County, PA Report (March 2002) by Kenneth Klemow of Wilkes University.
See Organization Contact Section
Elevation, Dissolved Oxygen, Who Update and Datasource attributes added to the dataset.
New datapoints heads up digitized and added by GPS over time.

Relates to the anthracite coal field. 1=Northern, 2=Eastern Middle, 3=Western Middle, 4=Southern

DL.DT: Resource_Description:Data can be requested by contacting EPCAMR for the EPCAMR Version or USGS for their version.
